contentrichtext.text: {{Multiple issues|notable = July 2008|primarysources = July 2008}} '''Brad Garton''' (born 1957) is an American [[composer]] and [[computer music]]ian who is professor of [[music]] at [[Columbia University]]. He has written, or helped to write, a number of computer music applications, including [[Real-Time Cmix]],<ref>{{cite web | title = What is CMIX? | publisher = [[Princeton University]] | url = http://www.music.princeton.edu/winham/whatiscmix.html | accessdate =2008-07-14 }} </ref> music synthesis and [[signal processing]] language for real time composition. He received his doctorate in composition from [[Princeton University]].<ref name="CU">{{cite web | title = Brad Garton | publisher = [[Columbia University]] | url = http://www.music.columbia.edu/cmc/people/brad.html | accessdate =2008-07-14 }} </ref> Garton is director of the [[Computer Music Center]], Columbia University, formerly the [[Columbia-Princeton Electronic Music Center]].<ref name="CU" /> Garton grew up in [[Columbus, Indiana|Columbus]], [[Indiana]].<ref>{{cite web | last = Garton | first = Brad | authorlink = | coauthors = | title = Another Part of the Two Square Miles | work = {{convert|2|sqmi|km2}} | publisher = [[Columbia University]] | month = May | year = 2005 | url = http://www.music.columbia.edu/~brad/writing/papes/2-square miles.html | accessdate =2008-07-14 }} {{Dead link|date=September 2010|bot=H3llBot}} </ref> His father, Robert, has served more than 30 years as a Republican in the Indiana state Senate, including a long term as Senate Pro Tem.<ref>{{cite web | last = Garton | first = Brad | title = Brad Garton misc. page | work = | publisher = [[Columbia University]] | url = http://www.music.columbia.edu/~brad/misc/index.html | accessdate =2008-07-14 }} </ref> Garton majored in pharmacy as a Purdue University student, but spent much of his time on music. Billing himself as "Mr. Science",<ref>{{cite web | last = Garton | first = Brad | authorlink = | coauthors = | title = Brad Garton Music | work = | publisher = [[Columbia University]] | date = | url = http://www.music.columbia.edu/~brad/music/ | accessdate = }} </ref> Garton provided sound effects and keyboards for the band [[Dow Jones and the Industrials]] in the late 1970s and early 1980s. He also produced many acts, making a heavy contribution to the [[Music of Indiana#Punk rock|Indiana music scene]], and with Richard K. Thomas founded Zounds Studios, which continues to produce music and sound for theater.<ref name="CU" /> He talked about his life and his formation as a musician in an interview with Peter Shea in December of 2007.<ref>http://ias.umn.edu/2007/02/01/garton-brad/</ref> ==References== <References /> {{Authority control|VIAF=45242993}} {{Persondata <!-- Metadata: see [[Wikipedia:Persondata]]. --> | NAME = Garton, Brad | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION = | DATE OF BIRTH = 1957 | PLACE OF BIRTH = | DATE OF DEATH = | PLACE OF DEATH = }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Garton, Brad}} [[Category:1957 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:American composers]] [[Category:People from Columbus, Indiana]]
